title: An Outlier on the High End of Normal
question_text:
An outlier is an observation that falls more than $1.5$ IQR's above the third quartile or more than $1.5$ IQR's below quartile I.
According to this definition, which of the following $z$-scores is the smallest $z$-score that would correspond to an outlier on the high end of a standard normal distribution?
solution:
IQR stands for Interquartile Range and can be calculated as follows:
IQR=Q3−Q1 where Q3 is the quartile 3 value and Q1 is the quartile 1 value. We do not need to use actual values, however. We can work through this calculation using only z-scores.

In the standard normal distribution, the mean is 0 and the median is also 0. The quartile 3 value is at the 75th percentile. That is, 75% of the observations will fall below this value, or the area to the left of this value is 0.75.

We can find the z-score associated with Q3 using the TI83/84 calculator's invnorm function. The invnorm function finds the z-score associated with a given area to the left.

The syntax is: invnorm(area to the left).

To find this z

(invnorm)
Enter 0.75

Press Enter

to be z=0.68

will produce similar answers. The only difference will be in the rounding. However, the final answer of Choice 'C' will be the same as it is the smallest value provided that would be considered an outlier on the high end.
